March 21, 1993: Fiction
THE CLIENT, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $23.50.) A deadly secret, revealed
by a lawyer just before he commits suicide, presents serious problems for an 11-
year-old boy.
THE BRIDGES OF MADISON COUNTY, by Robert James Waller. (Warner,
$14.95.) A photographer and a lonely farmer's wife in Iowa.
THE TALISMANS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $22.)
The fourth and concluding volume in a series about a fantasy land.
THE CHILDREN OF MEN, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $22.) In 2021, when Britain is
a police state and the human race is approaching its end, an Oxford historian
struggles with his fate.
NOVEMBER OF THE HEART, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $22.95.) In
Victorian-era Minnesota, a servant hopes to win an heiress's heart by helping her
family win a yacht race.
ALONG CAME A SPIDER, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $21.95.) Detective
Alex Cross on the trail of a psychopathic serial killer in Washington.
DEGREE OF GUILT, by Richard North Patterson. (Knopf, $23.) The case of a
woman journalist charged with killing an eminent novelist.
GRIFFIN & SABINE, by Nick Bantock. (Chronicle Books, $17.95.) The romance of
an artist and a secret admirer, told through cards and letters.
ALL THE PRETTY HORSES, by Cormac McCarthy. (Knopf, $21.) The adventures
of a 16-year-old vaquero from Texas in the Mexico of 1950.
EINSTEIN'S DREAMS, by Alan Lightman. (Pantheon, $17.) A series of fantasies
said to be dreamed by Albert Einstein in 1905.
DRAGON TEARS, by Dean Koontz. (Putnam, $22.95.) Two police detectives try
to cope with a demonic serial killer in southern California.
TO GREEN ANGEL TOWER, by Tad Williams. (DAW, $25.) The third and
concluding volume in the fantasy series "Memory, Sorrow and Thorn."
MCNALLY'S RISK, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $22.95.) The sleuth Archy
McNally investigates the history of a Palm Beach woman and the mysterious
deaths that are linked to her.
WAITING TO EXHALE, by Terry McMillan. (Viking, $22.) The friendships and
romances of four black women in Phoenix.
DISNEY'S ALADDIN, adapted by Don Ferguson. (Mouse Works/Penguin USA,
March 21, 1993
Non-Fiction
HEALING AND THE MIND, by Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $25.) Conversations with
physicians, scientists, therapists and patients about the relationship of sickness to
thoughts and emotions.
THE WAY THINGS OUGHT TO BE, by Rush H. Limbaugh 3d. (Pocket, $22.)
Anecdotes and opinions offered by the talk show host.
WOMEN WHO RUN WITH THE WOLVES, by Clarissa Pinkola Estes. (Ballantine,
$20.) A Jungian analyst reinterprets myths and folk tales to enable women to
understand their psyches.
OFFICIAL AND CONFIDENTIAL, by Anthony Summers. (Putnam, $25.95.) The
life of J. Edgar Hoover, head of the F.B.I. from 1924 to 1972.
BANKRUPTCY 1995, by Harry E. Figgie Jr. with Gerald J. Swanson. (Little,
Brown, $19.95.) The authors predict the collapse of America under Government
debt and suggest ways to cope with it.
THE SILENT PASSAGE, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $16.) The
psychological and social significance of menopause for today's women.
ASSEMBLING CALIFORNIA, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.)
Investigations into the geological history of California.
PREPARING FOR THE TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY, by Paul Kennedy. (Random
House, $25.) A Yale historian assays social and political forces and how they will
affect the future.
THE TE OF PIGLET, by Benjamin Hoff. (Dutton, $16.) Aspects of Taoist
philosophy explained through the actions of an A. A. Milne character.
CARE OF THE SOUL, by Thomas Moore. (HarperCollins, $20.) A
psychotherapist's discussion of spirituality and everyday life.
MARLENE DIETRICH, by Maria Riva. (Knopf, $27.50.) The legendary actress as
remembered by her daughter.
AROUND THE CRAGGED HILL, by George F. Kennan. (Norton, $22.95.)
Philosophical meditations on the world and its future.
NOBODY NOWHERE, by Donna Williams. (Times Books/Random House, $21.)
The autobiography of an autistic woman.
MAKING THE MUMMIES DANCE, by Thomas Hoving. (Simon & Schuster, $25.)
The reminiscences of the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
LIBERATION MANAGEMENT, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $27.50.) How American
